image.altText: A man with a moustache in front of a party tent.

items.synopsis: The Queensland Supreme Court heard Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden lived at home in what was a "dysfunctional, toxic relationship".

title.children: Gold Coast councillor charged with murdering his stepfather released on bail after urgent hearing

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: The ACCC alleges Qantas kept advertising and selling tickets for thousands of flights that had already been cancelled.

title.children: Qantas sold thousands of tickets to cancelled flights, ACCC alleges in new court action

image.altText: An aerial photo of the snowy mountain hydro-electric complex at dusk.

items.synopsis: The government reveals planned expansions to the Snowy Hydro have suffered an incredible $10 billion blowout over price estimates given by former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull six years ago.

title.children: Snowy Hydro expansion hits reset button as costs blow out to $12 billion

image.altText: Anthony Albanese with his hands up.

items.synopsis: With South Australia and Tasmania considered the key states in contest in the Voice to Parliament referendum, the prime minister hits Hobart after his visit to SA yesterday to announce the date of the referendum.

title.children: 'Convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes': Albanese spruiks Voice in Hobart on first full campaign day

image.altText: A view of the Liddell coal-fired power plant from across a lake, with swans in the foreground

items.synopsis: Much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems over the next decade, and as soon as this summer, without rapid investment in both electricity generation and transmission.

title.children: 'Imminent and urgent investment' required as national energy grid faces reliability fears ahead of hot summer

image.altText: Gloved hands hold a selection of vapes above a bin of multi-coloured objects.

items.synopsis: A state school on Queensland's Gold Coast turns away from its hardline stance on vaping, in favour of an educational approach that's now being shared with other schools.

title.children: This school abandoned automatic suspensions for vaping. Here's what happened

image.altText: A woman with brown hair holding a drink.

items.synopsis: Human remains which were found beside a busy highway in Goulburn have been identified as a Sydney woman who was murdered by her former boyfriend.

title.children: Human remains found by busy highway confirmed to be those of murdered Sydney woman

image.altText: A close-up shot of Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner, who wears a suit and tie

items.synopsis: The council's multi-million-dollar Housing Supply Action Plan will waive infrastructure charges on thousands of eligible builds across high-density areas, aimed at pushing the private sector to complete more projects faster.

title.children: Brisbane City Council reveals plans to boost housing supply as Queensland's homelessness crisis deteriorates

image.altText: The wreckage of a plane crash

items.synopsis: A coroner has criticised the aviation watchdog for failing to mandate a critical early warning device for pilots in the wake of a catastrophic plane crash in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Crash disaster inquest finds 'essential, readily available' warning system could have saved lives

image.altText: A woman surfs the internet through her Blackberry in Jakarta

items.synopsis: The 20-year-old network is still relied on by older mobile phones, baby monitors and medical devices.

title.children: Australia's biggest telcos are pulling the pin on their 3G networks, and it won't just be old mobile phones affected

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane is visible through a window at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: The assistant treasurer says it's "entirely uncontroversial" to say that Qantas must remain profitable, as the government weathers criticism over a decision to block Qatar from adding more flights, potentially reducing airfares.

title.children: Minister walks back comments that government intervened to protect Qantas' profits

image.altText: A young white woman leaning next to a house window

items.synopsis: Ruby Callaghan has tried for six months to stop one of the world's retail giants from charging her unwanted fees. The federal government says it is looking at introducing legislation, known as "don't be a jerk laws", to help curb the issue.

title.children: Ruby tried to cancel her Amazon account in March, but got stuck in a 'subscription trap'

image.altText: A woman leans against a tree with a Redfern sign behind her.

items.synopsis: While Yes voters in Redfern are hoping against heartache, the No campaign is targeting the undecided in Western Sydney.

title.children: How 'the Black capital of Australia' will be voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Jaymz Lester-Stevens is lying in a hospital bed, with a blue hospital gown with hands up. Medical equipment all around.

items.synopsis: Bowel cancer affects more than 15,000 Australians every year, but a rise in cases among people below the age of 50 has specialists reiterating the warning signs.

title.children: Jaymz, 26, thought he was losing weight, until a bowel cancer diagnosis changed his reality

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Whichever way the referendum goes, there will be enormous ramifications for reconciliation and Indigenous advancement. There will be political consequences felt all the way to the next election — and the next six weeks absolutely matter, writes David Speers.

title.children: The differences between a referendum and an election help explain why the Voice's Yes camp is so confident

image.altText: A woman standing in a vacant lot

items.synopsis: Multiple Victorian home owners have made complaints to the state's building authority over allegedly defective works they say have left them hundreds of thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Andrea thought she was building the home she'd retire in. $1 million later, she and her family are in a 'nightmare'

items.synopsis: Born out of anti-government rallies during the pandemic, authorities say Germany's Reichsbürger movement is a growing threat. And it's forging ties with one of the country's biggest political parties.

title.children: Peter Fitzek says Germany doesn't exist. So he declared himself the king of a new 'kingdom'

image.altText: Woman in blue shirt looks out sombrely between tree branches, short grey hair.

items.synopsis: Nathan Markl's body was found two weeks after he went missing, but an autopsy could not determine a cause of death. As an inquest is confirmed, his mother says she won't rest until she finds out what happened.

title.children: Two years after her son was found dead in a river, Jo is still looking for answers

image.altText: A wide shot of the camera on wheels.

items.synopsis: Debt collectors are pursuing nearly $33 million in unpaid seatbelt fines which have increased following new cameras on the roads and higher fines, and a spokesperson insists it's about saving lives, not making money.

title.children: Unpaid seatbelt fines in Queensland more than double in two years to more than 40,000

image.altText: A dilapidated old hut

items.synopsis: A hut that belonged to a Brisbane bayside figure will be demolished to make way for a controversial white water rafting stadium, but the council promises to pay tribute to her.

title.children: Wreckers move in on shack of legendary suburban 'Goat Lady' who will be immortalised for Olympics

image.altText: An e-scooter on its side on fire on a road in Marble Bar

items.synopsis: Firefighters say children were riding an e-scooter when it "combusted without warning". They say parts of the popular vehicles can pose significant fire risk.

title.children: 'Jostled' battery, heat blamed as e-scooter combusts with children on board

image.altText: Jim Chalmers speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: The competition watchdog has launched legal action against Qantas for allegedly selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled, while the ASX has opened flat. Follow live.

title.children: Treasurer says allegations Qantas sold tickets for cancelled flights 'deeply concerning', ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello there. I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be taking you through all the financial news this afternoon! FYI - the Australian share market is still pretty flat at the middle of the trading day. The benchmark ASX 200 index was up a tiny 0.02% to 7298 points at 12:00pm AEST. The broader All Ordinaries was up 0.1% to 7514 points. (For live figures at any time, head to the start of the blog and open the post at the very top.) The energy sector continues to drag, down 2.5%, with consumer non-cyclicals also down 1.4%. Financials are up 0.7% and utilities up 0.5%. The top movers are: Lake Resources +4.6% IGO +4.5% Link Administration +4.4% Syrah Resources +3.6% Domain Holdings +3.1% The bottom movers are: Whitehaven Coal -9.1% Healius -7% Sayona Mining -6% Webjet -5.6% Chalice Mining -4.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still flat at lunch

children.content: Hello there.
I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be taking you through all the financial news this afternoon!
FYI - the Australian share market is
still pretty flat
at the middle of the trading day.
The benchmark
ASX 200 index was up a tiny 0.02%
to 7298 points at 12:00pm AEST.
The broader
All Ordinaries was up 0.1%
to 7514 points.
(For live figures at any time, head to the start of the blog and open the post at the very top.)
The energy sector continues to drag, down 2.5%, with consumer non-cyclicals also down 1.4%.
Financials are up 0.7% and utilities up 0.5%.
The top movers are:
Lake Resources
Link Administration +4.4%
Syrah Resources +3.6%
Domain Holdings +3.1%
The bottom movers are:
Whitehaven Coal -9.1%
Healius -7%
Sayona Mining -6%
Webjet -5.6%
Chalice Mining -4.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Home retailer Harvey Norman has posted a full year net profit of $540 million, higher than market expectations of around $460 million. However, the results were more than a third down on last year's profit of $811 million. Harvey Norman enjoyed strong sales and profits during the COVID-19 pandemic, with customers buying home furnishings and office supplies during lockdowns. But franchise and company-operated sales revenue was down this year as many Australians struggle with the rising cost of living. Chairman Gerry Harvey said the company has delivered 40% growth in net assets since the beginning of the pandemic. "Our balance sheet remains strong with total assets of $7.67 billion, anchored by a $4 billion property portfolio." While the majority of its stores are in Australia, Harvey Norman has stores across 8 countries including New Zealand, Singapore and Ireland. The retailer plans to expand to 80 stores in Malaysia by the end of 2028, including a further 8 stores this year. The company will pay a final dividend of 12 cents per share, taking the full-year dividend to 25 cents per share, down from 37.5 cents last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Harvey Norman results beat expectations

children.content: Home retailer Harvey Norman has posted a
full year net profit of $540 million
, higher than market expectations of around $460 million.
However, the results were
more than a third down on last year's profit
of $811 million.
Harvey Norman enjoyed strong sales and profits during the COVID-19 pandemic, with customers buying home furnishings and office supplies during lockdowns.
But franchise and company-operated sales revenue was down this year as many Australians struggle with the rising cost of living.
Chairman Gerry Harvey said the company has delivered 40% growth in net assets since the beginning of the pandemic.
"Our balance sheet remains strong with total assets of $7.67 billion, anchored by a $4 billion property portfolio."
While the majority of its stores are in Australia, Harvey Norman has stores across 8 countries including New Zealand, Singapore and Ireland.
The retailer plans to expand to 80 stores in Malaysia by the end of 2028, including a further 8 stores this year.
The company will pay a
final dividend of 12 cents per share
, taking the full-year dividend to 25 cents per share, down from 37.5 cents last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has responded to the allegations made by the ACCC this morning regarding selling tickets to cancelled flights. Here's the airline's statement in full: "Qantas takes these allegations by the ACCC seriously," it said. "We have a longstanding approach to managing cancellations for flights, with a focus on providing customers with rebooking options or refunds. It's a process that is consistent with common practice at many other airlines. "It's important to note that the period examined by the ACCC between May and July 2022 was a time of unprecedented upheaval for the entire airline industry. "All airlines were experiencing well-publicised issues from a very challenging restart, with ongoing border uncertainty, industry wide staff shortages and fleet availability causing a lot of disruption. "We will examine the details of the ACCC's allegations and respond to them in full in court."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas responds to ACCC over cancelled flight sales allegations

children.content: Qantas has responded to the allegations made by the ACCC this morning regarding selling tickets to cancelled flights.
Here's the airline's statement in full:
"Qantas takes these allegations by the ACCC seriously," it said.
"We have a
longstanding approach to managing cancellations for flights
, with a focus on
providing customers with rebooking options or refunds
. It's a process that is consistent with
common practice at many other airlines
"It's important to note that the period examined by the ACCC between May and July 2022 was a time of unprecedented upheaval for the entire airline industry.

"All airlines were experiencing well-publicised issues from a very challenging restart, with ongoing border uncertainty, industry wide staff shortages and fleet availability causing a lot of disruption.
"We will examine the details of the ACCC's allegations and respond to them in full in court."

image.altText: A man wearing a wet purple tshirt stands in knee-deep water filled with tree branches in the street

items.synopsis: Video footage and photographs from the region around Idalia's landfall showed ocean waters washing over highways and neighbourhoods swamped by extensive flooding as residents inspected the damage.

title.children: 'All hell broke loose': Hurricane Idalia tore down houses and flooded neighbourhoods in Florida

image.altText: A man in a shirt and blazer with the top button undone gestures with his hands as he speaks.

items.synopsis: Greens housing spokesman Max Chandler-Mather says rents are going up at the fastest rate in 35 years. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Greens housing spokesman Max Chandler-Mather on rent increases. Here's what we found

image.altText: Close up of southern cassowary

items.synopsis: Only about a dozen southern cassowaries are believed to be living in this north Queensland rainforest. Researchers are piecing together a theory behind their dwindling numbers.

title.children: Why researchers are scouring remote forests for a glimpse of this 'secretive' species

image.altText: A group of pedestrians walking along a footpath by the Yarra River on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The approaching new season follows a dry winter for the east coast, and records broke in major cities for the warmest winter on record.

title.children: Spring tipped to bring scorching temperatures and below average rainfall

image.altText: A composite image of people on a couch with T-shirts saying M, PG, R, and colourful classification ratings advertising.

items.synopsis: There have been calls for a "vulgar" card game making light of the holocaust, rape and incest to be removed from store shelves this week. But the Australian Classification Board says it has no plans to start rating tabletop games.

title.children: Should board games have classification ratings like films, TV and video games?

image.altText: A composite of four people's faces - three women and one man.

items.synopsis: Over nine weeks of hearings, witnesses told of how a paedophile nurse was left to operate inside a children's ward, how school children were not believed, and about widescale abuse facing youth detainees in a "monster" prison.

title.children: In their words: The harrowing stories told to Tasmania's commission of inquiry

image.altText: A Samoan woman sitting in red and black patterned outfit with short white hair and red flower behind her ear.

items.synopsis: Samoa's Prime Minister Fiame Naomi Mata'afa has raised deep concerns about the mass exodus of Pacific Island workers to Australia and New Zealand.

title.children: Pacific countries are not 'outposts' to grow labourers for Australia, Samoan PM says

image.altText: Ron Pattenden with imagery of ACBF documentation in the background.

items.synopsis: Five former directors and officers of the failed funeral insurer Youpla are facing fines, after the corporate watchdog ASIC commenced civil proceedings over an arrangement to send the funds to a company in Vanuatu.

title.children: 'Trying to hit the stars': ASIC takes legal action against collapsed company directors

image.altText: Mitch MConnell freezes up while talking.

items.synopsis: The Republican senator froze up for more than 30 seconds while taking questions from reporters, prompting renewed calls for term limits in an ageing political arena.

title.children: 'It's time for term limits': US politicians respond to senator Mitch McConnell freezing up again

image.altText: A view shows a portrait of Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin at a makeshift memorial.

items.synopsis: The Kremlin says that investigators are considering the possibility that the plane carrying mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin was downed on purpose, the first explicit acknowledgement that he may have been assassinated.

title.children: Kremlin says Prigozhin's death may have been a 'deliberate atrocity'

image.altText: A brightly metallic coloured beetle on the back of a white hand

items.synopsis: As insect populations decline, researchers and start-ups are looking to tech as a solution. But some fear it may create more harm.

title.children: 'Where are all the Christmas beetles?': The far-reaching effects of insect extinction
